section.title: What is drools?
section.p: drools is a dynamic rules engine for Java, based upon the Rete algorithm and supported by a pluggable semantics modules.

section.title: What's Rete?
section.p: Rete is an algorithm devised by Charlse Forgy in the early 1980's to efficiently match conditions of rules when many objects are being observed by many rules. It's basically a structure to allow progressive relational joins across tables.

section.title: Relational joins? I want objects!
section.p: Yes, folks want objects, but Rete works in terms of tables and tuples. Thus, I've modified the algorithm, named my adapatation Rete-OO, which is described in this PDF document.

section.title: What's a Semantic Module?
section.p: Rules are written against objects, but the concept of an 'object' is fairly arbitrary, and completely customizable using Semantic Modules. A Java Semantic Module may regard any XML document simply as an object of type org.dom4j.Document, while an XML Semantic Module may differentiate between documents based upon their root element's name and namespace-uri. It's up to you.

section.title: How is drools designed?
section.p: Information regarding the design and implementation of drools may be found in this PDF document.
